_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INEOS Joliet, LLC - Joliet Facility EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) Executive Summary

Introduction and Policies 

The INEOS Joliet, LLC- Joliet Site, hereinafter INEOS is located at 23425 West Amoco Road in Channahon, Illinois. The Joliet facility was purchased from Flint Hills Resources LLC on November 30, 2018. 

The Joliet Site is a stationary source subject to Clean Air Act Section 112r and 40 CFR 68. The Joliet Site may hereinafter be referred to as "Site" or "facility". INEOS is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for the employees, the public, and the environment. INEOS has established a system to ensure the safe operation of the processes at this facility as part of this commitment. The RMP (Risk Management Program) is a part of this system that not only intends to manage the risks and/or hazards of the processes but also complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's Regulation 40 §CFR 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: the RMP rule. This executive summary is to comply with the RMP Plan requirement of the RMP Rule (40 CFR §68.150 through 40 CFR §68.195). 

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

INEOS is committed to the welfare of its employees, the public, and to the preservation of the environment. INEOS implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. In the event of an accidental release, INEOS will conduct emergency response action to help prevent or minimize injury to the public and the environment. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

The facility, operated by INEOS, is an intermediate chemicals facility located in Channahon, Illinois. The facility processes various chemicals that serve as intermediate materials to produce polyester fibers, fiberglass gasoline tanks, paints, wire coatings, plastics, insecticides, and food additives. As part of its Maleic Anhydride unit (MAN Process), the facility uses n-Butane, an EPA RMP-cove

red chemical, in quantities greater than the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs. The n-Butane Sphere contains a maximum inventory of 3,344,146 lbs of n-Butane.

The facility is subject to the OSHA process safety management standard, 29 CFR 1910.119, and regulated under EPA Risk Management Program 40 CFR Part 68 Program Level 3 requirements. 

Prevention Program 

The INEOS Joliet Chemical Plant MAN process is operating under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program. Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and an emphasis on safety have contributed to process safety at the facility. The prevention program has identified hazards and taken steps to prevent potential accidental chemical releases. The executive summary details the management system in place to implement this prevention program. 

The facility has had no RMP chemical release accidents over the last 5 years. 

Process Safety Information 

Documents are maintained describing process safety information for the MAN process. These documents describe chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and treatments, and emergency response considerations are provided in safety data sheets. The process operators use a computerized control system to assist them in managing the MAN process within the design ranges. 

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical ratings of equipment, piping and instrument drawings, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance ac

tivities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are properly maintained. 

Process Hazard Analysis 

The Site performs and updates risk assessments of the covered processes to ensure systematic identification and control of process hazards. These risk evaluations include off-site consequences, possible environment consequence, and public impact. This program has been established to ensure that hazards associated with the RMP regulated process are controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place. The studies are conducted using a cross functional team of personnel who have operating, maintenance, and engineering experience in the process been evaluated. A Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study, along with a Layers of Protection (LOPA) study and Checklist, is the methodology used to perform these evaluations. 

A HAZOP study of the MAN process unit is completed every five years. 

The HAZOP team's recommendations for improvement are reviewed with management, and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each recommendation is documented, retained, shared and made available to affected employees.  

Operating Procedures 

Written procedures are maintained under the ISO9000 program for the MAN process and address various modes of process operations, including such activities as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup following a turnaround or after an emergency shutdown. These procedures are used as a reference and refresher by experienced process operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new process operators. Operating procedures are reviewed annually and are required to be reviewed by operations personnel as part of the recertification process. The procedures are located in t

he unit control room for ready-reference by process operators and are available electronically to all Facility employees on the Facility's internal information system.  

Training 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Site has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in chemical plant operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks and procedures. After the new operator demonstrates (i.e. through tests, skills demonstration, etc.) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. All operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three years. This training is documented, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

Mechanical Integrity 

Practices and procedures are under continuous development and improvement to effectively maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures and plans, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. The combination of these activities forms a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to ensure that they perform their job in a safe

manner. Written procedures ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed on process equipment to ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment complies with design standards and specifications.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. The facility incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 

Management of Change 

The Site management of change (MOC) program ensures proper reviews are conducted, hazards are assessed, and a safe operation environment is maintained during and after the introduction of a change in the covered processes. Each MOC (permanent or temporary) includes a risk assessment to identify potential hazards of a change such as (1) process equipment, (2) chemicals, (4) technology (including process operating conditions), and other facility changes. The MOC system ensures that all documentation is updated, and training is completed prior to the commissioning of the change. MOC approval and action items are tracked to resolution.  Personnel affected by the change are informed and/or trained as prescribed by the MOC. 

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)

PSSRs are conducted for any new facilities or modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, equipment, procedures, and personnel are properly prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure that construction is completed in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the

construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention measures are properly implemented.

Compliance Audits

The Site performs PSM and RMP compliance audits at least every three (3) years. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are reviewed with site management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained. 

Incident Investigations 

The Site investigates all incidents that reasonably could have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment. The incident investigation procedure requires an investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts, identify the root cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards results to management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Employee Participation

The Site encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from compiling and updating technical information to participating as a member of a team that systematically analyzes new and modified processes for hazards (Process hazard analysis and managemen

t of change reviews (MOC)). Teams that represent a cross-section of levels and areas of the facility are formed to revise, update safety standards, and provide comments to site policies. The site investigation programs investigate engage site personnel as part of the investigation team and issue reports to affected personnel. 

Employees also participate on established safety site programs: Site Safety Committee Rangers, unit safety meetings, site safety leaders meetings, behavioral safety program, job safety analysis (JSA), auditing safety programs and emergency response team (ERT) amongst others. 

Employees have access to all information created as part of the Site prevention program. 

Hot Work Permit 

The Facility has a hot work permit program that details areas which require a permit and those areas for which a permit is not required. A permit is required in process areas for all cutting, welding, spark producing equipment, etc., except in designated areas. 

Safe Work Practices 

Safe work practices are in place to ensure worker and process safety. Detailed and rigorous safety standards control entry into work areas and confined spaces, specify procedures to follow for isolating energy sources by lockout/tag-out and describe the permitting process for completing work in the facility. There are procedures for cleaning and isolating all major pieces of equipment. Safety standards and work procedures are reviewed annually by all personnel who use them.

Contractors 

The Site uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the Site has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inf

orm Site personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, (4) safe work practices prior to start working and (5) stop work authority. The Site evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. 

Also, all  employees of contractors must complete the Three Rivers Manufacturing Council Safety Course before they are allowed to work at the facility. Contractor employees must recertify in this course annually. The facility evaluates contractor employer safety programs and performance during the selection of the contractor. INEOS personnel periodically conduct contractor performance evaluations to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations. 

Emergency Response Program 

The site maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect workers and the public as well as the environment. The program includes procedures for responding to a release of an RMP-regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is released. The procedures address aspects of emergency response, including first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and personnel accountability after an evacuation; notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs; and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. The Facility has procedures in place that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.

The site has an emergency response team composed of trained volunteers (employees) supported by onsite dedicated contract emergency response personnel.   Employees receive training to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency res

ponse program is updated based on modifications made to facility processes or emergency response procedures. 

The overall emergency response program for the Facility is coordinated with the Will County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which involves local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. The Facility has the capability of communicating with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire departments, industrial neighbors, and mutual aid with industry) around-the-clock. This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident and facilitating response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Facility conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and local emergency response organizations. Additionally, the Facility provides occasional refresher training to local emergency responders.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps 

Process hazards are managed to ensure continued safe operation. The PSM Program summarized previously is applied to the MAN production process. Collectively these program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures/human errors. 

In addition to PSM, the facility has instrumentation and equipment to detect, contain, and reduce the consequences of a release at and around the MAN production unit and associated n-Butane sphere, including but not limited to: 

Release Detection 
-	Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms 
-	Process instrumentation to detect density, temperature, level, and pressure changes 

Release Containment/Control 
-	Atmospheric relief devices 
-	Valves to permit isolation of the process 
-	Automated shutdown systems 
-	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (i.e., uninterruptible power supply for the process control system) 
-	Inert gas purge system 
-	Level indication on butane sphere 
-	Butane tend

er transfers coordinated with plant operations and 3rd party pipeline personnel 
-	Operating procedures addressing tender transfers 
-	LEL detection around sphere storage area 

Release Mitigation
-	Containment of liquid releases
-	Fire suppression and extinguishing systems 
-	Remote/local actuated deluge system 
-	Trained emergency response personnel 
-	Emergency response equipment located onsite

Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

The Facility resolves all findings from HAZOP studies, some of which result in modifications to the process. The resolutions and resulting changes are tracked internally to ensure completion. Capital projects are continually identified and implemented through this risk assessment process.

Five-Year Accident History 

The Facility has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past five years. If an incident were to occur, it would be investigated by a qualified team to determine a root cause and prevent a similar occurrence from happening again. No incidents meeting the 68.42 criteria have occurred in the previous 5 years.
